001package imagingbook.common.geometry.moments;
002
003import imagingbook.common.geometry.basic.Pnt2d;
004import imagingbook.common.math.Complex;
005
006/**
007 * <p>
008 * Naive implementation of Flusser's complex invariant moments [1]. See Sec.
009 * 8.6.5 (Eq. 8.51 - 8.54) of [2] for additional details.
010 * This abstract class defines static methods only.
011 * </p>
012 * <p>
013 * [1] J. Flusser, B. Zitova, and T. Suk. “Moments and Moment Invariants in
014 * Pattern Recognition”. John Wiley and Sons (2009). 
015 * <br>
016 * [2] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing &ndash; An
017 * Algorithmic Introduction</em>, 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
018 * </p>
019 * 
020 * @author WB
021 * @version 2022/11/17
022 */
023public abstract class FlusserMoments {
024        
025        private FlusserMoments() {}
026        
027        /** Length of moment vector returned by {@link #getInvariantMoments(Iterable)}. */
028        public static final int N = 11; // 11 moment invariants
029        
030        /**
031         * Calculates and returns a vector of 11 invariant moments
032         * for the specified set of 2D points.
033         * 
034         * @param points a set of 2D points
035         * @return the vector of invariant moments
036         */
037        public static double[] getInvariantMoments(Iterable<Pnt2d> points) {
038                Complex c11 = getScaleNormalizedMoment(points, 1, 1);
039                Complex c12 = getScaleNormalizedMoment(points, 1, 2);
040                Complex c21 = getScaleNormalizedMoment(points, 2, 1);
041                Complex c20 = getScaleNormalizedMoment(points, 2, 0);
042                Complex c22 = getScaleNormalizedMoment(points, 2, 2);
043                Complex c30 = getScaleNormalizedMoment(points, 3, 0);
044                Complex c31 = getScaleNormalizedMoment(points, 3, 1);
045                Complex c40 = getScaleNormalizedMoment(points, 4, 0);
046                
047                double p1 = c11.getRe(); 
048                double p2 = c21.multiply(c12).getRe();
049                double p3 = c20.multiply(c12.pow(2)).getRe();
050                double p4 = c20.multiply(c12.pow(2)).getIm();
051                double p5 = c30.multiply(c12.pow(3)).getRe();
052                double p6 = c30.multiply(c12.pow(3)).getIm();
053                double p7 = c22.getRe();
054                double p8 = c31.multiply(c12.pow(2)).getRe();
055                double p9 = c31.multiply(c12.pow(2)).getIm();
056                double p10 = c40.multiply(c12.pow(4)).getRe();
057                double p11 = c40.multiply(c12.pow(4)).getIm();
058                
059                return new double[] {p1, p2, p3, p4, p5, p6, p7, p8, p9, p10, p11};
060        }
061        
062        /**
063         * Returns the scale-normalizes complex moment of order (p,q)
064         * for the specified set of 2D points.
065         * 
066         * @param points a set of 2D points
067         * @param p order index p
068         * @param q order index q
069         * @return the moment value
070         */
071        public static Complex getScaleNormalizedMoment(Iterable<Pnt2d> points, int p, int q) {
072                int xS = 0;
073                int yS = 0;
074                int n = 0;
075                for (Pnt2d pnt : points) {
076                        xS = xS + pnt.getXint();
077                        yS = yS + pnt.getYint();
078                        n++;
079                }
080                
081                double a = n;
082                double xc = xS / n;
083                double yc = yS / n;
084                Complex sum = new Complex(0, 0);
085                for (Pnt2d pnt : points) {
086                        double x = pnt.getX() - xc;
087                        double y = pnt.getY() - yc;
088                        Complex z1 = (x == 0.0 && y == 0 && p == 0) ? 
089                                                        Complex.ZERO : new Complex(x, y).pow(p);        // beware: 0^0 is undefined!
090                        Complex z2 = (x == 0.0 && y == 0 && q == 0) ? 
091                                                        Complex.ZERO : new Complex(x, -y).pow(q);
092                        sum = sum.add(z1.multiply(z2));
093                }
094                checkForNaN(sum);
095                return sum.multiply(1.0 / Math.pow(a, 0.5 * (p + q) + 1));
096        }
097        
098        private static void checkForNaN(Complex z) {
099                if (z.isNaN()) {
100                        throw new RuntimeException("NaN encountered in complex quantity");
101                }
102        }
103        
104}
